awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Measuring the Variable Composition and Chemistry of a Volcanic Plume Using a Distributed Sensor Network
awd_abstract_narration:
This RAPID project supports the deployment of a network of low-cost sensors on the Big Island of Hawaii to measure the production rate of sulfate aerosols during the current eruption of the Kīlauea volcano. Sulfate aerosols are of particular interest due to their role as an air pollutant at ground level that causes respiratory health effects and their role in the upper atmosphere as having a potential cooling impact on climate. 

A network of low-cost sensors at ground level around the Kīlauea volcano will measure the chemical conversion rates of primary gases, such as sulfur dioxide, to secondary air pollutants, such as sulfate aerosols, and assess how these rates vary under different atmospheric conditions (e.g., humidity, temperature, sunlight, cloudy vs. clear air). This research also will demonstrate the feasibility of using low-cost sensors as part of monitoring and emergency response efforts during extreme air quality events, such as wildfires. The uncertainty about the duration of the volcanic eruption at Kīlauea requires that this work be supported through a RAPID so that the research can be conducted while the eruption is ongoing. The results of this study will have implications for human health, air quality policy and emissions regulation, and climate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Introduction

Our research project aimed to investigate air pollution from volcanic activity on the Island of Hawai`i using an innovative approach: low-cost air quality sensors. This project is among the first to collect long-term observations from volcanic plumes, providing valuable insights into the atmospheric impact and behavior of volcanic eruptions. The network of sensors also served a dual purpose by monitoring public air quality during eruptions and facilitating educational outreach.

Key Findings

One of the most significant outcomes of our research was the detailed observation and analysis of the chemical conversion processes of sulfur dioxide (SO₂) to particulate matter (PM). Volcanic plumes are rich in SO₂ gas and understanding its transformation into fine particles is crucial for assessing both environmental and public health impacts. Our findings indicate that the conversion rate of SO₂ to sulfate aerosols in volcanic plumes is influenced by several factors, including emission rates and atmospheric conditions.

Our measurement data revealed that the rate of SO₂ conversion to particulates varies with environmental conditions. For instance, higher humidity levels and increased sunlight exposure were found to accelerate the conversion process. These findings are vital for improving atmospheric models that predict the dispersion and impact of volcanic emissions.

Public Air Quality Monitoring

The network of low-cost sensors also played a crucial role in community air quality monitoring air quality near active volcanoes. During several eruptions, including the first eruption of Mauna Loa in over 40 years, real-time data from the sensors provided critical information on air quality levels to support timely public health advisories and interventions. The affordability and ease of deployment of these sensors make them a good option for continuous air quality monitoring in remote and resource-limited regions.

Educational Impact

A key component of our project was the integration of our findings and data into educational activities. We collaborated with local schools and teachers to develop activities that incorporated real-world data on air pollution and volcanic activity. This hands-on approach not only enhanced students' understanding of environmental science but also fostered greater community awareness and engagement with air quality issues.

Educational activities included classroom experiments, data analysis exercises, and interactive lessons on the science of air pollution and volcanology. The real-time data from our sensor network provided a unique opportunity for students to engage with current scientific research and understand its relevance to their daily lives.

Conclusion

This project successfully demonstrated the utility of low-cost air quality sensors in both scientific research and public health monitoring. By providing detailed insights into the chemical conversion of volcanic emissions and facilitating real-time air quality monitoring, we have contributed valuable knowledge to the field of atmospheric science. Additionally, our educational outreach efforts have helped to bridge the gap between scientific research and community engagement, fostering a more informed and proactive approach to air quality management.
